ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I would recommend any course by Don Kagan to anyone ever. This class will show anyone why the humanities matter in life.

Kagan is wonderful and engaging and smart. The subject isn't the most riveting one in the world, but he makes it matter. His retirement is a great loss for the University, and I was honored to be in his last class. As a man, a scholar, and a professor, he is unbeatable.
I would highly highly recommend it. It is such a pity it has to come to an end.

The best class that I have taken at Yale. Learning directly from Professor Kagan was an experience that I will never forget. The subject matter was also incredibly interesting, and I wish I could've taken more of his Greek history seminars.

really, the best class at Yale. The most effectively taught class at Yale; the nicest professor at Yale; the best historian at Yale. I'm sorry there're no more opportunities to take a course from him.

I apologize to all who read this evaluation but no longer have the privilege to study with Donald Kagan. Thucydides and the Peloponnesian War was the greatest seminar I ever took in my life, better than every seminar the History Department offers. Professor Kaganâs insight, warmth and humor are unmatched among faculty. He is a ÏÎ¹Î»ÏÏÎ¿ÏÎ¿Ï in the truest sense of the word: Only his love of students, Yale, and football compare to his love of wisdom.As he concluded our course and his decades-long career, âVivat Yale.â

What an experience to have been part of Prof. Kagan's last course! Almost as good as an amphibious landing.Gender balance could have been better; wish there had been more engagement with contemporary methods of Thucydides scholarship.
I would recommend the class especially if you are a history major. The material is really interesting.

I would whole-heartedly recommend the course to another student. It is sad (but very understandable) that it won't be taught again. The course is a thorough review of the Peloponnesian War using ancient texts (primarily Thucydides). It is seminar style.
